snippet.textDisplay:
The girl in second video is a not a good example at all. I stopped watching her videos due to the consent bad information. A texturize is NOT the same as a relaxer and doesn’t come close. Texturizes also hardly work depending on your curl pattern. If you’re going to educate people educate them.


Also, I’m against relaxers not because I want people to take care of their hair but because I’m sick of the normalization. It’s to the extent those of us that our natural don’t get has much job opportunities. We are looked at like, “they relaxed theirs so for you to work here you need to be less of a distraction and do the same”. The worst part is charter and private schools are often against it too. They expel and suspend children over their natural hair.
snippet.textOriginal:
The girl in second video is a not a good example at all. I stopped watching her videos due to the consent bad information. A texturize is NOT the same as a relaxer and doesn’t come close. Texturizes also hardly work depending on your curl pattern. If you’re going to educate people educate them.


Also, I’m against relaxers not because I want people to take care of their hair but because I’m sick of the normalization. It’s to the extent those of us that our natural don’t get has much job opportunities. We are looked at like, “they relaxed theirs so for you to work here you need to be less of a distraction and do the same”. The worst part is charter and private schools are often against it too. They expel and suspend children over their natural hair.

snippet.textDisplay:
It's interesting. There's a white girl I work with (should mention I'm white too) with SUPER tight curls. She says when she takes the days to straighten her hair, she thinks it looks ugly in her. But, the interesting part is that she keeps it fairly short because when she let's it grow, her curls get awkwardly loose.

I'm curious if this happens to black women/men, or if it could be happening to her cause the density of her hair strands isnt the same thickness.
snippet.textOriginal:
It's interesting. There's a white girl I work with (should mention I'm white too) with SUPER tight curls. She says when she takes the days to straighten her hair, she thinks it looks ugly in her. But, the interesting part is that she keeps it fairly short because when she let's it grow, her curls get awkwardly loose. 

I'm curious if this happens to black women/men, or if it could be happening to her cause the density of her hair strands isnt the same thickness.

snippet.textDisplay: Hi Brad! I work in a machine shop, which is a temperamental environment because we work around hot ovens/kilns and sometimes chemicals from the machines (mostly coolant) can splash/mist around you when you operate them. I have to wear my hair in a bun for safety since my hair is down my back and I often cover it with a rag when I’m running a machine that is misty. Because of this my hair curls nicely and has lots of volume from the bun but I have to wash it more frequently than I used to and it gets dry/breaks more at the ends so they get thin. How can I minimize the damage of having to wear my hair up for 9.5 hours a day? Would braiding be as damaging? Or should I consider not as long of a length? I would still have to tie it back for safety as long as the length is long enough to become tangled in my machine. Please help! Thank you!
snippet.textOriginal: Hi Brad! I work in a machine shop, which is a temperamental environment because we work around hot ovens/kilns and sometimes chemicals from the machines (mostly coolant) can splash/mist around you when you operate them. I have to wear my hair in a bun for safety since my hair is down my back and I often cover it with a rag when I’m running a machine that is misty. Because of this my hair curls nicely and has lots of volume from the bun but I have to wash it more frequently than I used to and it gets dry/breaks more at the ends so they get thin. How can I minimize the damage of having to wear my hair up for 9.5 hours a day? Would braiding be as damaging? Or should I consider not as long of a length? I would still have to tie it back for safety as long as the length is long enough to become tangled in my machine. Please help! Thank you!

snippet.textDisplay: I got a relaxer when I was 17. I got 1st degree burns on my scalp. It was bleeding and scabbed. All of my hair broke off and fell out. I basically had a chemical hair cut. So I was basically bald and scabbed up. Worst mistake of my life. My boob length curly hair went to broken ear length hair. Been trying to recover ever since, and still haven’t been able to. I don’t recommend them for anyone. I’m still struggling 😭😭😭😭😭😭😭
snippet.textOriginal: I got a relaxer when I was 17. I got 1st degree burns on my scalp. It was bleeding and scabbed. All of my hair broke off and fell out. I basically had a chemical hair cut. snippet.textDisplay: I’m sorry but I know this is a stupid question.  If you get a perm do you still take care of your hair like you would if it was natural?  Im just asking because I’ve been thinking about getting one so it’d be nice to learn a little more, thank you 😊

snippet.textDisplay: I stopped doing relaxers in 2013. My first one was done when I was 7 years old! I liked how low maintenance it was but when I hit high school, I started bleaching and dying my hair (it wasn't too damaged). One day I decided to bleach and dye the bottom half of my hair red like always, well not even 2 weeks later my mom told me it was time for my perm 😥. My fear since about 8 was my hair coming out in my hands when I washed the perm out, well that happened in 2012. I was DEVASTATED! I had a panic attack. Once I got out and blow dried everything, it just looked like my hair was. Cut into an A cut. Literally EVERYONE loved my hair. I would thank them for the compliments but cry internally. The back of my hair was a good 2 inches long while the front was about 8-10inches. From that moment I started regrowing my hair but didnt go natural until 2013 and never brought myself to do the big chop. I slowly transitioned until the permed hair was fully gone. Now its 2020 and if I ever get tired of my natural  curl hair, I just straighten it. My curly hair takes 2hrs to detangle properly, to twist my hair up fully (like dreads but two strand twist) it can take anywhere from 5-9hrs easily. So many people see my hair and want to do it but once they get in it, they regret starting. I've thought of perming my hair again but its just too healthy to go backwards in my progress. I'll just get a silk press if all else fails.
snippet.textOriginal: I stopped doing relaxers in 2013. My first one was done when I was 7 years old! I liked how low maintenance it was but when I hit high school, I started bleaching and dying my hair (it wasn't too damaged). One day I decided to bleach and dye the bottom half of my hair red like always, well not even 2 weeks later my mom told me it was time for my perm 😥. My fear since about 8 was my hair coming out in my hands when I washed the perm out, well that happened in 2012. I was DEVASTATED! I had a panic attack. Once I got out and blow dried everything, it just looked like my hair was. Cut into an A cut. Literally EVERYONE loved my hair. I would thank them for the compliments but cry internally. The back of my hair was a good 2 inches long while the front was about 8-10inches. From that moment I started regrowing my hair but didnt go natural until 2013 and never brought myself to do the big chop. I slowly transitioned until the permed hair was fully gone. Now its 2020 and if I ever get tired of my natural  curl hair, I just straighten it. My curly hair takes 2hrs to detangle properly, to twist my hair up fully (like dreads but two strand twist) it can take anywhere from 5-9hrs easily. So many people see my hair and want to do it but once they get in it, they regret starting. I've thought of perming my hair again but its just too healthy to go backwards in my progress. I'll just get a silk press if all else fails.

snippet.textDisplay: My mom use to relax my hair when I was younger because that was just all she knew about hair. But I have been natural now for 3 years and I have to say my hair feels and looks better than it ever did. When my hair was relaxed it wouldn’t grow past my ears and now it’s grazing my shoulders. I loved my big chop I went with a super short pixie cut. One thing I really struggled with was due to me being 3/4c I have a lot of shrinkage and because of that I wasn’t seeing much growth but it was there it’s just the more it grows the more it compacts to somehow stay the same length but when I blow dry it I’m always amazed.
snippet.textOriginal: My mom use to relax my hair when I was younger because that was just all she knew about hair. But I have been natural now for 3 years and I have to say my hair feels and looks better than it ever did. When my hair was relaxed it wouldn’t grow past my ears and now it’s grazing my shoulders. I loved my big chop I went with a super short pixie cut. One thing I really struggled with was due to me being 3/4c I have a lot of shrinkage and because of that I wasn’t seeing much growth but it was there it’s just the more it grows the more it compacts to somehow stay the same length but when I blow dry it I’m always amazed.

snippet.textDisplay: Not all relaxers are the same! I have very curly hair and use a relaxer. If you are white, you can still use a relaxer, but you want the one for kids. It's less harsh and for finer hair. Works like a dream.
snippet.textOriginal: Not all relaxers are the same! I have very curly hair and use a relaxer. If you are white, you can still use a relaxer, but you want the one for kids. It's less harsh and for finer hair. Works like a dream.

Hey Brad, I'm not sure if you only react to YouTube videos, but there is a great documentary called "Good Hair" by Chris Rock. It documents the importance of hair in black culture and is pretty enlightening. Maybe you could give a review of the techniques used and the hair industry as a whole.

Thanks❤

snippet.textDisplay: Relaxers are bad for your hair 100% no matter what. BUT if you are going to do it, keep in mind that it is not ever supposed to burn your scalp, because just like bleach, that means that you will get chemical burns on your scalp and then you'll get those gross oozing scabs.
snippet.textOriginal: Relaxers are bad for your hair 100% no matter what. BUT if you are going to do it, keep in mind that it is not ever supposed to burn your scalp, because just like bleach, that means that you will get chemical burns on your scalp and then you'll get those gross oozing scabs.

snippet.textDisplay: fun fact: relaxers became popular because very curly hair was seen as unprofessional for jobs, whereas straight hair was seen as the end-all-be-all. Then relaxers became a staple for ease in black and brown communities :)
snippet.textOriginal: fun fact: relaxers became popular because very curly hair was seen as unprofessional for jobs, whereas straight hair was seen as the end-all-be-all. Then relaxers became a staple for ease in black and brown communities :)

snippet.textDisplay: I'm a white woman who had a black best friend growing up. When we were in our teens, she wanted her hair relaxed and asked ME to do it. Probably not the best idea to ask the white chick, but she's helped bleach my hair a few times, so... why not? Neither of us knew anything about it. By some miracle of God, it actually came out good. Only one problem. She wore some silver necklaces, and some of the relaxer got on the necklaces and turned the metal BLACK. Permanently. And I think we both nearly died on the fumes lol.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm a white woman who had a black best friend growing up. When we were in our teens, she wanted her hair relaxed and asked ME to do it. snippet.textDisplay: My EX-hairstylist used me as a guinea pig and put the strongest relaxer she could find on my  100% Caucasian 3A-B-ish hair before the advent of Brazilian blow out. The first clue I should have had to run away is that she decided to read the instructions in the box while leading me to believe she knew what she was doing. Long story short, I paid $100 for third degree chemical burns on my scalp and neck and hair that was so fried, it just broke off in chunks at the ends. I’ve learned to love my curls, frizz and all.
snippet.textOriginal: My EX-hairstylist used me as a guinea pig and put the strongest relaxer she could find on my  100% Caucasian 3A-B-ish hair before the advent of Brazilian blow out. The first clue I should have had to run away is that she decided to read the instructions in the box while leading me to believe she knew what she was doing. Long story short, I paid $100 for third degree chemical burns on my scalp and neck and hair that was so fried, it just broke off in chunks at the ends. I’ve learned to love my curls, frizz and all.

snippet.textDisplay: The beauty of natural hair is a journey. Going through the stages can be stressful but just giving up and relaxing hair to me is sad only because at a Point in time i did it and was not happy with none of it. It took a very long time for me to actually grow my natural hair to length i got it but as long as it’s healthy im fine with it

snippet.textDisplay: We grew up getting relaxers in the kitchen. I let go of the creamy crack years ago. While I’m natural, I don’t knock anyone who opts to permanently straighten. The upkeep of natural hair can be A LOT. I just wish that stylists were more diverse with their skills and be versatile with working with black hair processes.
snippet.textOriginal: We grew up getting relaxers in the kitchen. I let go of the creamy crack years ago. While I’m natural, I don’t knock anyone who opts to permanently straighten. The upkeep of natural hair can be A LOT. I just wish that stylists were more diverse with their skills and be versatile with working with black hair processes.

snippet.textDisplay: My late mom and I have long thick hair. It’s just genetic, and she absolutely REFUSED to put a relaxer in my hair as a kid. I’m glad she didn’t tbh, but I did get a mild relaxer every six months in my late 20s. I’ve since stopped due to my hair coming out from chemo. I might consider relaxers again, but my hair has grown a lot without it.
snippet.textOriginal: My late mom and I have long thick hair. It’s just genetic, and she absolutely REFUSED to put a relaxer in my hair as a kid. I’m glad she didn’t tbh, but I did get a mild relaxer every six months in my late 20s. I’ve since stopped due to my hair coming out from chemo. I might consider relaxers again, but my hair has grown a lot without it.
